articles.name: Posters Lost to Nazis Are Recovered, and Up for Sale
articles.description: Premier poster collections that were forfeited when the Nazis came to power in Germany and Austria are gradually going on the block after being returned to the owners’ families.

articles.name: From the Stiletto to the 'Comma'
articles.description: An exhibition of 170 shoes by Roger Vivier reflects the couture skills that the founder and his successor have brought to the brand.

articles.name: Seeing Like Klimt on an Austrian Lake
articles.description: A visit to Lake Attersee, where the painter Gustav Klimt created dozens of landscapes, frames the artist’s vision.

articles.name: Paying Artful Homage
Snoo Wilson, Surrealistic British Playwright, Dies at 64
articles.description: Mr. Wilson’s plays often had a satirical edge and included real people from history, like Darwin, Eichmann and Aleister Crowley.

articles.name: What the Brain Can Tell Us About Art
articles.description: When we view a work of art, we add our own brush strokes of memory — finishing a creative process that, until then, is incomplete.

articles.name: Postcard From Paris: Artaud and van Gogh
Uncanny Representations of Humans in Distress
articles.description: An exhibition at the Princeton University Art Museum showcases 26 of Edvard Munch’s etchings, lithographs and woodcuts, from the Museum of Modern Art.

articles.name: Descent Into Madness Entwines Van Gogh, Artaud at Paris Exhibition
articles.description: The shrieks of mad women assault visitors entering the Musee d'Orsay's new exhibit on Vincent Van Gogh, an arresting look at the painter's work as seen through the eyes of the late avant-garde French theatre director and playwright Antonin Artaud.

articles.name: Upstate NY: Home to Great Art in Unexpected Places
articles.description: Winslow Homers in the shadow of a defunct Beech-Nut baby food plant. A Rembrandt, Picasso, Rubens and Renoir up the hill from a paper mill. The founder of the Hudson River School vying for attention amid baseball memorabilia and old farm machinery.

articles.name: When Diamonds Are Dirt Cheap, Will They Still Dazzle?
articles.description: Technology has the potential to affect the value of items that are now rare and expensive, everything from diamonds to paintings and autographs.

articles.name: Gregory White Smith, Pollock Biographer, Dies at 62
articles.description: Mr. Smith was co-author of a controversial 1990 biography of Pollock that asserted the artist had homosexual relationships.

articles.name: Recently Attributed Leonardo Painting Was Sold Privately for Over $75 Million
Where’s the Appetite for Old Masters?
articles.description: As the price of art produced within the past 50 years soars, historical paintings and drawings of exceptional quality look jarringly inexpensive.

articles.name: Walter Isaacson to Deliver Jefferson Lecture
Art Matters | The Second Life of Performance
Extravagant Wedding Cakes Rise Again
articles.description: Couples are returning to big weddings with show-off cakes.

articles.name: Moving Leonardo’s Horse: A Question of Logistics or Pedigree?
articles.description: A statue that was meant to pay homage to a destroyed 15th-century work by Leonardo da Vinci has been relegated to a racetrack in Milan, far from the public eye. Now some are trying to find a more suitable home.

art_title: Luncheon on the Grass (Le Déjeuner sur l'herbe)

articles.name: Latest Swimwear Trends Have Wild Side This Season
articles.description: Welcome to the jungle.

articles.name: How Italy Cast a Spell Over Manet
articles.description: In "Manet: The Return to Venice," a far-ranging exhibition in the Doge's Palace in Venice, works are shown that illustrate how the Old Masters inspired the French artist.

articles.name: Crowds Line Up for Manet in Venice
Conn. Man Thought Linked to Heist Gets 2½ Years
articles.description: A reputed Connecticut mobster was sentenced Thursday to 2½ years in prison in a weapons and prescription drugs case that revealed federal authorities' belief that he knows something about the largest art heist in U.S. history.

articles.name: I Went to a Movie and an Art Exhibition Broke Out
articles.description: Manet comes to life in a film about an exhibition at the Royal Academy; it will be shown on Thursday in theaters.

articles.name: Louvre Abu Dhabi Gives Peek at Collection
articles.description: Abu Dhabi's new branch of the Louvre considers no artistic subject to be off limits but will not "shock for the sake of shocking", a top overseer said Tuesday. She spoke as the museum prepared to open a sample of its growing collection to public view, shedding light on the choices the city makes as it expands its international profile while testing how far to open its conservative culture.

artist: Francisco José de Goya y Lucientes
art_title: The Third of May. The execution of Spanish insurgents by Napoleonic troops under General Murat, on Principe Pio Hill, Madrid, May 3, 1808

articles.name: Making An Operatic Hero of Goya
articles.description: For many years, Placido Domingo has wanted someone to write an opera on the life of Goya so that he could sing the role depicting his Spanish countryman. And for many years, Gian Carlo Menotti has wanted to write another major opera to ease some of the pain he suffered from the poor reception accorded his last one, ''Juana, La Loca.'' And for many more years, Martin Feinstein has craved to draw the music world's attention to his young but rocketing Washington Opera. On Saturday night, the tenor, the composer and the impresario will all get their wish with the premiere of ''Goya.''

articles.name: IRISH REPORT NO PROGRESS IN FINDING STOLEN ART
articles.description: The authorities were on the alert at airports and docks today for the valuable paintings stolen from a mansion south of Dublin, but news reports suggested that the works, among them a Vermeer and a Goya, might have already been taken out of the country. ''There's been no breakthrough today - no progress,'' an Irish police spokesman said today. The paintings were stolen Wednesday in a predawn theft at Russborough House, 15 miles southwest of Dublin.

articles.name: PAINTINGS ARE STOLEN IN IRELAND
articles.description: Thieves stole 17 paintings worth up to $45 million, including works by Vermeer and Goya, from a mansion in Ireland early today. The seven least valuable paintings were found near an abandoned van within hours. The works were stolen from Russborough House, the home of Sir Alfred Beit in County Wicklow, 20 miles southwest of Dublin. Two of the seven recovered paintings, found by boys going fishing near the mansion, were damaged, although the police said they did not know how badly.

articles.name: Goya Grotesquery Laid to Lead's Use
articles.description: Art historians have long speculated about the nature of a severe illness Goya suffered in the midst of his painting career that is generally thought to have caused a remarkable and abrupt transformation in the subject matter of his painting -- from pleasant court portraiture to grotesque social commentary.

articles.name: Books of The Times; A Magnificent Book Displays the Greatness of Goya
articles.description: F J Sanchez Canton book Goya revd; profuse illus noted; Goya por

articles.name: Letters to the Editor; Corning Caesars' Zen Self-Portrait? Western Vedanta Puerto Rican Literature

art_title: The Company of Frans Banning Cocq and Willem van Ruytenburch (The Night Watch)

articles.name: REMBRANDT CHARGE DRAWS HOT DENIALS; Experts Split on Validity of Van Dyke's Belief That Hun- dreds Are False. METROPOLITAN IS UPHELD Assertion That Those in Mu- seum Are All Spurious Is Ridi- culed and Robinson Smiles. ARTIST'S INVENTORY CITED Document Listing 200 Paintings ls Given as Proof That More Than 35 Are Genuine.
articles.description: A furore was caused in the art world yesterday by Professor John C. Van Dyke's book charging that there were only thirty-five real Rembrandts in existence and that none of the paintings in the Metropolitan Museum of Art ascribed to the Dutch master was genuine.

articles.name: REMBRANDT AND THE FACTORY SYSTEM.
articles.description: For full thirty years Professor JOHN VAN DYKE has carried a guilty secret in his bosom. He knew that most of the pictures sold at high prices and cherished in museums, because they were ascribed to REMBRANDT, were not Rembrandts.

articles.name: NO REAL REMBRANDT HERE, SAYS VAN DYKE; Rutgers Professor Repudiates All of the Metropolitan Museum's Fifteen.
articles.description: Assailing the Rembrandt tradition as a huge mistake which has misled art lovers and critics for more than a century, John C. Van Dyke, Professor of Art and Archaeology at Rutgers College, has made a complete redistribution of the paintings of the Rembrandt school, with the startling result that he can find but a scant 35 of the 800 or 1,000 paintings attributed to the master that are the work of his hand.

artist_bio: Claude Monet, born Oscar Claude Monet (14 November 1840  5 December 1926) was a founder of French impressionist painting, and the most consistent and prolific practitioner of the movement's philosophy of expressing one's perceptions before nature, especially as applied to plein-airlandscape painting. The term Impressionism is derived from the title of his painting Impression, Sunrise (Impression, soleil levant).

articles.name: Monet's 'Water Lilies' Auctioned in NY for $27M
articles.description: A Claude Monet painting out of the public eye for decades sold Tuesday for just over $27 million, leading the bidding at an auction of art from the estates of heiress Huguette Clark, businessman Edgar Bronfman and other major collectors.

articles.name: Your Tuesday Briefing
articles.description: What you need to know to start your Tuesday: deaths in Ukraine, climate change at home, and 10 years after “Friends.”

articles.name: Report: Art Treasures in Gurlitt's Austrian House
articles.description: Austrian state television says experts have found 180 artworks — including a long-lost painting by Claude Monet — in the Salzburg house of the German art collector who hoarded art in his Munich apartment for decades.

articles.name: German Collector to Return 1st Looted Artwork
articles.description: A recluse who hoarded a priceless art collection at his homes in Germany and Austria — including works possibly looted from Jewish owners by the Nazis — has for the first time agreed to hand back a piece of art, his representatives said Wednesday.

articles.name: Today in History
articles.description: Today is Tuesday, April 15, the 105th day of 2014. There are 260 days left in the year.

articles.name: German Recluse Gurlitt to Return Nazi-Looted Art: Media
articles.description: A German recluse whose billion-dollar art hoard was confiscated will return all works looted by the Nazis to their owners or their descendants, his legal custodian told German media on Wednesday.
